pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:1.1.3: “Break its authority” renders cakkabheda. Sp.1.410: Cakkabhedāyāti āṇābhedāya, “Cakkabhedāya: by breaking the authority.” The break in authority is presumably both from the Buddha and the Sangha. Although the Buddha was the only authority in laying down rules, the Sangha was autonomous in its decision making. For practical purposes, it was the Sangha that Devadatta was breaking with.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:2.9: For these eighteen grounds, see Kd 17:5.2.3.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:2.13: In the rule “taking up” renders both samādāya and paggayha. As a consequence, the two terms are here rendered in the same way.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss10:2.62: The Pali text just says dukkaṭa, without specifying that it is an āpatti, an offense. Yet just below the text says that the dukkaṭa is annulled if you commit the full offense of saṅghādisesa. The implication is that dukkaṭa should be read as āpatti dukkaṭassa, “an offense of wrong conduct”.
